weekly_top_story.headline: Federal Government Shuts Down, Disrupting Key Healthcare Programs
weekly_top_story.summary: The federal government shutdown that began October 1, 2025, has halted non-essential services, caused the expiration of key healthcare provisions—including the Acute Hospital Care at Home waiver—and disrupted Medicare and Medicaid operations, creating widespread uncertainty for providers and patients nationwide[1].

stories.headline: Telehealth Access Shrinks as Medicare Restrictions Return
stories.summary: Effective October 1, 2025, Medicare no longer covers most phone-only telehealth visits, reinstates pre-pandemic geographic and originating site restrictions, and requires in-person visits for some services—changes likely to reduce access, particularly for rural and homebound patients, unless Congress intervenes[4][5].

stories.headline: CMS Releases Final Guidance for Medicare Drug Price Negotiation Program
stories.summary: CMS has issued final guidance for the third cycle of its Medicare Drug Price Negotiation Program, outlining procedural updates and preparing for the next round of drug price announcements amid ongoing White House pressure to lower pharmaceutical costs[1].

stories.headline: California Health Care System Reels From Federal Budget Cuts
stories.summary: California’s health care system is facing major disruptions due to recent federal budget cuts to health care and social services, with clinics and providers—especially those serving low-income populations—warning of reduced access and increased strain on the state’s safety net[2].
